repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Interactive Environmental
            Learning and Science Promotion Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Interactive
            Environmental Learning and Science Promotion Project for
            Honduras was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was substantial, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Following some of the lessons learned from the project:
            Project activities benefit from building partnerships and
            networking with the nonprofit sector, the private sector,
            universities, and other donor agencies. Introducing learning
            by demonstrating concepts has tremendous value, both in
            training and in developing exhibits for facilities. In any
            type of construction project involving government and an NGO
            such as the Profuturo Foundation, a high degree of trust
            among the different agencies is essential. For an
            institution such as the ILC, the establishment of a
            nongovernmental organization/foundation to manage the center
            with a significant endowment is a prerequisite. The original
            drivers that spurred the development of the GDLN were the
            ability to utilize Information and Communications
            Technologies to import training and capacity building to the
            public sector. Even after a single year of operations,
            clearly the GDLN's presence in Honduras can achieve its
            original financial sustainability goals. The network has
            evolved and now offers Honduras real opportunities to
            connect to the global knowledge economy.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Interactive Environmental
            Learning and Science Promotion Project (PROFUTURO)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Interactive Environmental Learning
            and Science Promotion Project (PROFUTURO) aims to encourage
            and expand Honduran scientific, environmental, and cultural
            knowledge and management in the context of the
            borrower's sustainable development needs and ethnic
            diversity. The project has three components. The first
            component designs and implements an interactive learning
            center (ILC) as a non-formal educational facility focused on
            the social, scientific, and environmental requirements for
            sustainable development, to be used by children, teachers,
            and parents. The project emphasizes the pre-Hispanic
            contribution, specifically research on the practices and
            scientific knowledge of pre-Hispanic cultures; trains local
            residents, including indigenous residents, as guides for the
            COPAN park (a park of archeological ruins); and develops a
            conceptual framework for interactive archeological exhibits
            and workshops for children at the COPAN park. This component
            also consists of archeological parks subprojects. The second
            component supports capacity building for the staff and
            volunteers of the ILC and the development of an ILC
            communication strategy. The third component designs and
            implements a management plan for archeological parks.
